meanings.definition: As a verb: to gather or assemble (a group of people or things)
meanings.sent1: The teacher asked the students to muster in the schoolyard for the fire drill.
meanings.sent2: The farmers mustered their livestock before the storm arrived.
meanings.sent3: Trying to muster all the courage she had, Sarah stepped onto the stage for her first performance.
meanings.sent4: After the defeat, the team mustered their spirits to prepare for the next match.
meanings.sent5: The children mustered all their toys to build a fort in the living room.

meanings.definition: As a noun: a formal gathering of troops for inspection or display
meanings.sent1: The general oversaw the muster of soldiers before they marched into battle.
meanings.sent2: The annual military muster was a grand event with flags flying high.
meanings.sent3: The muster turned into a festive occasion with music and celebrations.
meanings.sent4: The muster of troops resembled a colorful parade through the town.
meanings.sent5: The soldiers stood in formation during the muster, awaiting orders.

meanings.definition: As a verb: to summon up (a feeling, attitude, or response)
meanings.sent1: She tried to muster a smile despite feeling nervous about the presentation.
meanings.sent2: He mustered the strength to apologize to his friend for the misunderstanding.
meanings.sent3: The comedian struggled to muster a laugh from the tough crowd.
meanings.sent4: Even in the face of adversity, she mustered hope for a better tomorrow.
meanings.sent5: The team captain mustered determination to lead the players to victory.
